key_points: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i
e
the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth
learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin. The Convergence Factor is also known (on a Lamberts Chart) as the 'Constant of the Cone' or simply 'n'. The equation for convergency is: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Convergence Factor Correct Answer: depends on the latitude of the parallel of origin and on difference n longitude f two positions.

key_points: On a Lambert chart, the characteristics of Great Circles and Rhumb Lines are as follows: For Great Circles: Meridians are depicted as straight lines

At any other latitude, Great Circle tracks take on a curved shape that is concave towards the parallel of origin
learning.explanation: On a Lambert chart, the characteristics of Great Circles and Rhumb Lines are as follows: For Great Circles: Meridians are depicted as straight lines. Near the parallel of origin, they appear nearly straight. At any other latitude, Great Circle tracks take on a curved shape that is concave towards the parallel of origin. For Rhumb Lines: Meridians are shown as straight lines. All other Rhumb Lines are concave toward the pole. This curvature is particularly noticeable in parallels of latitude. In the context of this Lambert chart, the standard parallels are 65ºN and 37ºN. The Parallel of Origin falls between these standard parallels, approximately at 51ºN. Consequently, when drawing a straight-line track from 49ºN 030ºW to 48ºN 040ºW, this track will be positioned south of the Parallel of Origin. The Great Circle track between these points will exhibit concavity toward the Parallel of Origin, which means it will be positioned south of the straight-line track. Similarly, the Rhumb Line Track will also show concavity towards the nearer pole and will lie on the equatorial side of the Great Circle Track. Therefore, it will be situated to the south of the Great Circle Track.

NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Compass Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 037º 16ºW 053º 2ºE 051º Aircraft’s True Track from the feature, QTE = 060º + 037º + 180º = 277º (T) Unlike the Mercator chart where chart convergence is zero, in a Lambert conformal chart the meridians merge with each other at the poles. To plot a bearing in a Lambert chart we must apply the chart convergence, because there is chart convergence between the meridians where the bearing is measured (aircraft) and from it will be plotted (NDB). If you plot the true bearing of the NDB from the aircraft 097º, in a Lambert char the plot will be correct. The problem is when you need to plot the reciprocal from the meridian of the NDB, the line will not pass through the aircraft position. learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. The Scale in Lambert conformal chart is only correct along the standard parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin.

On Simple conic projections, the ratio of the top angle of the segment, when the cone is developed, to 360º, is called "Constant of cone", "Convergency factor" or just "n" and is mathematically equal to the Sine of the parallel of origin

On a Lambert Conformal Projection chart, where the cone now cuts into the Earth and differs from the Simple conic in that there are now two latitudes (standard parallels) where the chart touches the reduced Earth, there is also a parallel of origin where the cone is parallel to the tangent and where Earth convergency is equal to the Chart convergency

learning.explanation: The Direct Mercator is a cylindrical projection and its parallel of origin is the Equatror. Generally, the scale for a Direct Mercator chart is given by the formula: Scale at any latitude = Scale at the Equator x 1/cos Latitude. The scale expands as the secant of the latitude. So, as scale varies with latitude, it is normal for a Mercator scale to be given at only one latitude, which is called "scale latitude" and for scale at other latitudes to be calculated using the formula above. When working with questions comparing distances and scales on a Mercator projection at different latitudes, we use the equation "ABBA": Earth DistanceA(or Scale LatA) x cos LatB = Earth DistanceB (or Scale LatB )x cos LatA. For this question, using the "ABBA" equation, we get: Scale at 22o x cos 35o = Scale at 35o x cos 22o ⇒ Scale at 22o = (200 000 x cos 22o) / cos 35o = 226 376. Therefore, the approximate scale at 22o00'N on a Direct Mercator chart is 1 : 226 000.

learning.explanation: The Direct Mercator is a cylindrical projection and its parallel of origin is the Equatror. Generally, the scale for a Direct Mercator chart is given by the formula: Scale at any latitude = Scale at the Equator x 1/cos Latitude. The scale expands as the secant of the latitude. So, as scale varies with latitude, it is normal for a Mercator scale to be given at only one latitude, which is called "scale latitude" and for scale at other latitudes to be calculated using the formula above. learning.explanation: The amount of the daylight hours depends on the latitude and how the Earth orbits the sun. The orientation of the Earth’s axis to the sun is always changing throughout the year, as we revolve around the sun. Sometimes the axis points towards and other times away from the sun. As this orientation changes throughout the year, so does the distribution of sunlight on Earth’s surface at any given latitude. People who live in the mid-latitudes, far from both the Equator and the poles, enjoy maximum daylight on the summer solstice and put up with maximum darkness on the winter solstice. Between the two extremes, sunlight increases or decreases each day, but the rate of change is not steady. The change of duration of daylight period is slowest in the June and December solstices (Solstice means “the Sun stands still”). It increases in the transition periods, and reaches its maximum halfway at the two equinoxes (when the sun is over the Equator). From its slowest of 1 minute per day in January and June it increases to 3 minutes in March and September.

learning.explanation: The Air Almanac includes tables that give the Local Mean Time (LMT) of sunrise and sunset and the LMT of the start of morning civil twilight and the end of evening twilight. The times given in the Air Almanac are calculated for the Greenwich meridian, but can be taken as LMT at all longitudes. The time of sunrise and sunset varies with latitude and time of the year. Higher latitudes experience longer days in the summer and shorter days in the winter, because of the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. The morning civil twilight starts when the centre of the Sun is 6o below the sensible horizon and ends at sunrise. And the evening civil twilight starts at sunset and ends when the centre of the Sun is 6o below the sensible horizon. For this question: Find the LMT end of the Evening Civil Twilight on 12th October 2017 interpolating for N67° 16' (between N66° - N68° and between 11th - 14th Oct): 17:36. Convert Arc to Time: Bodo airport is 14o 22' East off Greenwich, which corresponds to: 14º x 4 min + 22' x 4 sec = 57 minutes of time. Convert LMT sunset into UTC: The Earth rotates from West to East, thus the UTC end of Evening Civil Twilight at Bodo airport on 12th October 2017 is: 17:36 - 57 min = 16:39 UTC.
